summary: The appellant, Okerugwu Ogbonna, was charged with cheating under section 421 of the Criminal Code for fraudulently obtaining £3 from Victoria Peter by misrepresenting brass trinkets as gold. The prosecution proved that the appellant used false pretences—claiming the trinkets were valuable gold—to secure the loan. While the facts supported a conviction under section 419 (false pretences), the court held that the conviction under section 421 (cheating) could not stand due to lack of evidence that the appellant had gilded the trinkets or used any trick as required under section 421. The appeal was allowed, the conviction and sentence were set aside, and an acquittal was entered.
citations: Rex v Okerugwu Ogbonna, WACA/7, 6th November 1941
rationaleHighlights: No evidence that appellant gilded the trinkets or ordered the gilding
Section 421 requires proof of a 'trick' or fraudulent device
Conviction under section 421 cannot stand without evidence linking appellant to the gilding
Appeal allowed due to insufficient evidence for cheating charge
Court expressed disapproval of appellant's conduct despite acquittal
Distinction between false pretences and cheating emphasized
